Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client’s case grows more complex and requires detailed guidance
Story:
I stared at my computer screen, headset pressing into my ear, as another call connected. “Hello, this is Alex from BrightNet Services—” The prospect cut me off, launching into a barrage of technical questions about our new package. My script only skimmed the surface, and I felt the familiar pressure to keep the call moving, to handle objections smoothly, to close the sale. But the questions were valid, and I knew the answers mattered.

As soon as my shift ended, I switched hats—now, I was an advocate, meeting with a client whose legal case had grown tangled and urgent. She needed clear, precise advice, not vague reassurances. My mind kept drifting back to the calls, to the half-answers I’d given, and I wondered if I was doing the same here—skimming, simplifying, when what was needed was depth and honesty.

The expectations pressed in from both sides: efficiency and persuasion as a telemarketer, accuracy and thoroughness as an advocate. I felt torn, my conscience tugged in two directions, unsure how to reconcile the demands of my roles with the needs of the people depending on me.
